title: About
text:
This blog focuses on using machine learning to model electric vehicle (EV) energy consumption, especially in urban transportation. As EVs become more common, understanding how much energy they actually use in real driving conditions is an important problem for both sustainability and transportation planning.
Instead of looking at EVs only from a technical or engineering perspective, this blog takes a data-driven approach. Different factors, such as driving patterns, traffic, road conditions, and weather, can be used in machine learning models to predict EV energy consumption. Also, different types of models and what their strengths and limitations are in real-world applications are discussed.

title: Vehicle Dynalic Modelling
text:
One traditional approach to estimating EV energy consumption is vehicle dynamics modelling, which relies on physical laws to describe how a vehicle moves and consumes energy. These models typically calculate energy use based on forces acting on the vehicle, such as aerodynamic drag, rolling resistance, road gradient, and acceleration, along with battery efficiency [1]. By combining these components, vehicle dynamics models aim to estimate energy consumption over a given driving cycle.
Vehicle dynamics models are attractive because they are physically interpretable and grounded in well-understood principles of mechanics. Given accurate vehicle parameters and driving profiles, they can provide reasonable estimates of energy consumption and help explain how different factors contribute to energy use [1]. For example, they can clearly show how frequent acceleration, higher speeds, or uphill driving increase energy demand.
However, these models also have several limitations when applied to real-world urban driving. They often require detailed and vehicle-specific parameters, such as mass, drag coefficients, and powertrain characteristics, which may not always be available or easy to measure [1]. In addition, many assumptions are made to simplify the modeling process, such as constant efficiencies or idealized driving conditions, which may not hold in congested or highly variable urban environments.
As a result, while vehicle dynamics modelling provides a strong theoretical foundation for understanding EV energy consumption, its ability to scale across different vehicles, drivers, and cities is limited. These challenges have motivated researchers to explore data-driven alternatives, such as machine learning models, that can better capture the complexity and variability of real-world urban transportation systems [1].
Reference [1] X. Zhang, Z. Zhang, Y. Liu, Z. Xu, and X. Qu, “A review of machine learning approaches for electric vehicle energy consumption modelling in urban transportation,” Renewable Energy, vol. 234, p. 121243, Nov. 2024. doi:10.1016/j.renene.2024.121243

title: Machine Learning Models
text:
In recent years, machine learning models have become increasingly popular for predicting EV energy consumption, particularly in urban transportation scenarios where driving conditions are highly variable. Unlike physics-based or traditional statistical approaches, machine learning models learn patterns directly from data and do not rely on strong assumptions about the underlying relationships between variables [1]. This makes them well suited for capturing the complexity of real-world driving behavior.
A wide range of machine learning techniques has been applied to EV energy consumption modeling. Common approaches include tree-based models such as Random Forests and Gradient Boosting, as well as neural networks, which are capable of learning nonlinear relationships between energy consumption and input features like speed, acceleration, traffic conditions, road characteristics, and weather [1]. These models often achieve higher prediction accuracy than traditional methods, especially when large and diverse datasets are available.
One key advantage of machine learning models is their ability to handle high-dimensional and nonlinear data. Urban driving involves frequent stop-and-go behavior, varying traffic density, and complex interactions between variables, all of which can be difficult to model using simpler approaches [1]. Machine learning models can automatically learn these interactions, leading to improved performance in many practical applications.
At the same time, recent research has placed increasing emphasis on model interpretability, especially in the context of transportation and energy systems. Interpretable machine learning techniques, such as feature importance measures and partial dependence analysis, help identify which factors contribute most to EV energy consumption and how they influence predictions [1]. Improving interpretability not only builds trust in model outputs but also provides valuable insights for system design, policy-making, and driving behavior analysis, making machine learning models more useful beyond pure prediction tasks.
However, machine learning models also come with trade-offs. They often require large amounts of high-quality data and can be more difficult to interpret than statistical models or vehicle dynamics approaches [1]. As a result, researchers increasingly focus on balancing predictive accuracy with interpretability, depending on whether the model is intended for real-time prediction, system planning, or policy analysis.
Reference [1] X. Zhang, Z. Zhang, Y. Liu, Z. Xu, and X. Qu, “A review of machine learning approaches for electric vehicle energy consumption modelling in urban transportation,” Renewable Energy, vol. 234, p. 121243, Nov. 2024. doi:10.1016/j.renene.2024.121243

title: Introduction
text:
Electric vehicles (EVs) are often seen as an important solution for reducing carbon emissions from transportation, especially in cities where road traffic contributes a large share of CO2 emissions [1]. Compared to traditional internal combustion engine vehicles, EVs are more energy efficient and produce no direct tailpipe emissions, which makes them attractive for countries aiming to meet long-term climate goals [1]. Because of this, many governments are actively encouraging EV adoption through policies, incentives, and plans to phase out gasoline-powered vehicles.
However, despite these benefits, EV adoption still faces several real-world challenges. Issues such as limited driving range, battery performance, and charging availability continue to affect user experience. A key problem behind many of these challenges is the difficulty of accurately estimating EV energy consumption in real driving conditions, especially in complex urban environments where traffic, road conditions, and driving behavior vary constantly [1]. Reliable energy consumption predictions are crucial for reducing range anxiety, supporting route planning, and improving charging and energy management strategies.
Traditional methods for modeling EV energy consumption are often based on physical or rule-based models that rely on vehicle dynamics and predefined assumptions. While these models are grounded in physics, they usually require detailed vehicle parameters and struggle to adapt to different vehicles, cities, and driving patterns [1]. As a result, their performance can be limited when applied to large-scale, real-world urban transportation systems.
In recent years, machine learning has become an increasingly popular approach for modeling EV energy consumption. By learning directly from data, machine learning models can capture complex relationships between energy use and factors such as speed, acceleration, traffic conditions, weather, and driving behavior, often achieving better prediction accuracy than traditional methods [1]. This blog builds on recent research to explore how machine learning is used to model EV energy consumption in urban settings and why these approaches are important for supporting more sustainable and intelligent transportation systems.
Reference [1] X. Zhang, Z. Zhang, Y. Liu, Z. Xu, and X. Qu, “A review of machine learning approaches for electric vehicle energy consumption modelling in urban transportation,” Renewable Energy, vol. 234, p. 121243, Nov. 2024. doi:10.1016/j.renene.2024.121243

title: Statistical Method
text:
Before the widespread use of machine learning, many studies relied on statistical methods to model EV energy consumption. These approaches typically use regression-based models to relate energy use to a set of explanatory variables such as vehicle speed, acceleration, trip distance, road slope, and environmental conditions [1]. Common examples include linear regression and generalized linear models, which aim to capture average relationships between inputs and energy consumption.
Statistical models are often valued for their simplicity and interpretability. The estimated coefficients provide clear information about how individual factors influence energy consumption, making these models easier to understand and explain compared to more complex approaches [1]. For example, a regression coefficient can directly indicate how an increase in speed or acceleration is associated with changes in energy use.
However, statistical methods also have important limitations when applied to urban EV energy consumption. Many of these models assume linear relationships and independence among observations, assumptions that are frequently violated in real-world driving data where driving behavior and traffic conditions vary over time [1]. As a result, statistical models may struggle to capture nonlinear effects and interactions between variables, leading to reduced predictive performance.
Because of these limitations, statistical methods are often more suitable as baseline or exploratory tools rather than high-accuracy predictors. Their shortcomings in handling complex and highly variable urban driving conditions have motivated the shift toward more flexible machine learning approaches, which can better capture nonlinear patterns in EV energy consumption data [1].
Reference [1] X. Zhang, Z. Zhang, Y. Liu, Z. Xu, and X. Qu, “A review of machine learning approaches for electric vehicle energy consumption modelling in urban transportation,” Renewable Energy, vol. 234, p. 121243, Nov. 2024. doi:10.1016/j.renene.2024.121243

title: Recommendation
text:
While machine learning models have shown strong potential for predicting EV energy consumption, there are several directions where future research and applications can be improved. One important area is the integration of richer and more diverse data sources. Incorporating real-time traffic data, high-resolution weather information, road topology, and driver behavior data could further improve model accuracy and robustness, especially in complex urban environments [1].
Another key recommendation is to continue improving model generalizability. Many existing studies rely on data collected from specific cities, vehicle types, or driving conditions, which may limit how well models perform when applied elsewhere [1]. Future work should focus on developing models that can transfer across different regions and vehicle fleets, or on methods that allow efficient retraining with limited new data.
There is also a growing need to balance predictive performance with interpretability. While complex machine learning models can achieve high accuracy, their lack of transparency can reduce trust and limit practical adoption [1]. Future research should continue exploring interpretable machine learning techniques that provide meaningful insights into how different factors affect EV energy consumption, making these models more useful for planners and policymakers.
Reference [1] X. Zhang, Z. Zhang, Y. Liu, Z. Xu, and X. Qu, “A review of machine learning approaches for electric vehicle energy consumption modelling in urban transportation,” Renewable Energy, vol. 234, p. 121243, Nov. 2024. doi:10.1016/j.renene.2024.121243

title: Application in urban transportation
text:
Machine learning–based EV energy consumption models are not only useful from a research perspective, but also play an important role in real-world transportation systems. Accurate energy consumption predictions can support decision-making at multiple levels, from individual drivers to city planners and policymakers [1].
![Figure 1: EV charging] (Applications/urban.jpg)
Route Planning and Range Estimation
One of the most direct applications is route planning and range estimation. By predicting how much energy an EV will consume under different traffic conditions, road types, and driving behaviors, these models can help drivers choose routes that minimize energy use and reduce range anxiety [1]. This is especially important in urban environments where traffic congestion and frequent stops can significantly affect energy consumption.
Charging Infrastructure Planning
Energy consumption models are also valuable for planning and optimizing EV charging infrastructure. By understanding when and where EVs are likely to consume more energy, city planners and utility providers can better anticipate charging demand and decide where charging stations should be installed [1]. This helps improve accessibility while avoiding unnecessary over-investment in underused locations.
Energy and Transportation System Management
At a broader level, EV energy consumption modeling supports intelligent transportation systems and energy management. Aggregated predictions of EV energy use can be used to forecast electricity demand, coordinate charging schedules, and reduce stress on the power grid during peak hours [1]. These applications are particularly important as EV adoption continues to grow in densely populated urban areas.
Policy and Sustainability Analysis
Finally, machine learning models provide useful insights for policy evaluation and sustainability analysis. By identifying key factors that influence EV energy consumption, policymakers can design more effective incentives, regulations, and urban planning strategies to promote efficient and sustainable transportation [1]. In this way, EV energy consumption modeling contributes not only to technical optimization but also to long-term environmental and societal goals.
